title: Cullompton Walks

images.title: brian lee / Cullompton Mill Leat walk
images.caption: Cullompton Mill Leat walk. Passable by Wheelchair from town to Lower Mill and from Tesco's car park. There where a few tables and benches along this stretch but these where slowly eaten by local teenagers, no trace remains. A Kingfisher can be seen quite regularly in the mornings from the bridge (shown) around the corner to the remains of Middle Mill, nesting boxes can be seen here also.

images.title: brian lee / Cullomptons Lower Mill
images.caption: Cullomptons Lower Mill. The Lower Mill race and the end of hard standing, passable by wheelchair if you have the really thin version but ends in mud. The CCa fields are behind.The Mill from at least the 1670s is now a private residence. If you are on foot, left at the top brings you into the south of town by the Magistrates court.

images.title: brian lee / Upton Lakes, Cullompton
images.caption: Upton Lakes. The first of the lakes at Upton, 3 acres in total, the first being dug in 1904 holds some big Carp, Bream and Tench amongst others.

images.title: brian lee / Upton Lakes, Cullompton
images.caption: The lodges of Upton Lakes at the entrance with the Blackdown hills in the distance.

images.title: brian lee / Higher Mill, Cullompton
images.caption: Higher Mill, Cullompton. The first of the mills when approached from the B3181 end, this stretch prone to silt build up and then rushes would take root. The recent addition of ducks seems to have cut back on foliage problem, 20 years ago it was not uncommon to see men with scythes cutting it back. It dates back to at least the 1700's and the name Pidgeon searched online will bring up a better history. It is fed by the raised section across the B3181.

images.title: brian lee / Cullompton Mill Leat walk.
images.caption: Cullompton Mill Leat walk. The lower section before it drops into Lower Mill looking back up stream.

images.title: brian lee / Cullompton Mill Leat Walk
images.caption: Mill Leat Walk. The entrance to Cullomptons CCA fields at the end of the Leat walk. Passable by wheelchair only at speed. The CCA car park is a few hundred yards on the right. The area is used a lot by dog owners. The gate is a remnant from the days when Livestock was held on these fields.

images.title: brian lee / Higher mill race
images.caption: Higher mill race. Downstream of Cullompton Higher Mill, trout can be seen regular in the oxygenated waters of this stretch.

description: This interesting Mid Devon town is located on the River Culm near Exeter and Tiverton. The historic settlement includes a 15th century church, interesting old mills, a Grade I listed 17th century house and several Grade II listed buildings. For walkers there's lots of good options in the nearby Blackdown Hills AONB and through the pretty Culm Valley. This walk in the town takes you along the pretty mill leat walk on the eastern side of the settlement. There's a nice surfaced footpath taking you along the pretty waterway to the town's historic mills.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The Weary Traveller is a good choice for some post walk refreshment. They do a find carvery and also have a lovely large garden area for warmer days. You can find them on Station Road at postcode EX15 1BQ for your sat navs.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The easy paths make for a nice easy dog walk. The Weary Traveller mentioned above is also dog friendly.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: To the west you can visit the splendid Bickleigh Mill and pick up the Exe Valley Way for more riverside walking. For an alternative circular walk around the city see the Exeter Green Circle. This 12 mile trail visits the Alphin Brook Valley, the village of Alphington, the Hoopern Valley, Mincinglake Valley Park and The Ludwell Valley. To the north there's Uffculme where you can visit the lovely deer park on the Bridwell Estate. In the village there's also the historic Coldharbour Mill with its fascinating working wool museum. For more walking ideas in the area see the Blackdown Hills Walks and the Devon Walks pages.

display_address: Higher Mill Lane, Cullompton, Mid Devon, Devon, England, EX15 1AF, United Kingdom
